newsitem.title: USA: EPA starts childrens' environmental issues office.
newsitem.headline: EPA starts childrens' environmental issues office.

text.p: The Environmental Protection Agency said Thursday it had created a new office to deal with environmental health threats to children.
In a restructuring, the EPA also created new offices to oversee rewriting and improving regulations and to oversee expanding public information on local pollution.
"Through this restructuring we can advance our most significant initiatives by giving them new levels of support and leadership," EPA Administrator Carol Browner said in a statement.

Philip Landrigan, chairman of the Department of Community Medicine at Mount Sinai School of Medicine, will be senior adviser on children's health and a full-time staff director for the office will be named, the agency said.

The office will work to see that EPA standards protect children, coordinate children's issues throughout the agency, and research and set new policies on children's susceptibility and exposure to pollutants.
